This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE STATE OF THE ARMY
div.p: The Army is on the point of being submitted once again to a process of reform, but nobody knows for certain what form the new experiments are to take. How many times in the last thirty years has it found itself in the melting-pot? Has it indeed ever in that period been really free from the fames of disintegration? Every new Minister called to Fall Mall since the days of Lord Cardwell has felt that he had a mission to endeavor to create for us a new army on fresh and original lines. What wonder that as a result of all this recasting the last state is admittedly worse than the first. Matters were bad enough before the war in South Africa came to open the eyes of soldiers to the folly of political procedure. They have been rendered infinitely worse since, for change has followed change in quick succession since peace was declared in May, 1902.

There is no denying that when the present Secretary of State took charge of his portfolio on the change of Government occurring, the condition of things which faced him on his entrance to office was little short of deplorable. Never before, perhaps, in all its chequered history had the War Office been in such a condition of chaotic muddle. And the same state of chaos prevailed in most, if not all, commands at home and in the colonies. There had been so much rushing of fences that nobody seemed to know what was best to be done or who was responsible for anything, and the officials at Headquarter, when applied to for information, could do little bat shrug their shoulders and admit their own ignorance. It has been left for Mr. Haldane to endeavor to restore harmony, and to his credit be it said he has, to some extent, succeeded. Things are still bad, but they are unquestionably better than they were. But the present War Minister has to deal with a system which, however good it may look on paper, has been found in practice to be the cause of endless irritation and confusion. The idea of the existing administrative organisation was, of course, to promote decentralisation. Experience shows that it has not done this. Indeed, if anything, there is more centralisation than ever; for we are bound to a far greater extent than before to the exigencies of that red-tapeism which all sensible men recognise the folly of, and lose no opportunity of condemning. Of proper military control is scarcely a shred left, or rather there would not ha but for Mr. Haldane’s practical common-sense.

There is another feature entirely absent, and that is justice. It is the easiest thing for a Minister sitting in his office to issue mandates affecting services, arms, and departments; to lop off a million of money here and half a million there; to say that this method is old and that man old-fashioned. It not unusually follows that as the result of ill-considered action there is directly or indirectly punishment to be borne which innocent victims are required to grin and submit to. If our Army were officered and recruited under compulsory laws of service, as Continental armies are, change, constant change, would be bad enough. What makes our arrangement in confusion, as we will designate it, so very hard is that officers and men have all come forward of their own free will to render service to their King and country. Having done so; ’tis theirs not to reason why; ’tis theirs bat to do and die.” They surely deserve to be treated, therefore, with some consideration; hot this is the last thing, unfortunately, that they usually receive. Reference is constantly being made, not up direct terms, perhaps, but by insinuation, to the marked tendency which the rising population is evincing not to accept fierce in the Army. Have we not seen lately commissions given in both the cavalry and the Guards to young men who have undergone no examination whatever? Can we wonder at parents displaying an inclination not to send their sons to the Army after all that has happened since the war? Could any other result be looked for, considering the treatment which has been meted out to officers of high rank and distinction ? The Army for the last four years has been handed over bodily to faddists. We trust they are satisfied with their work. Soldiers cannot but regard the situation with feelings of doubt and concern; they would, indeed, be poor soldiers if they did not.
(“Army and Navy Gazette”.)

div.head: CATHOLIC PILGRIMMAGE TO PALESTINE.
div.p: A pilgrimage to Palestine is being organized by the Assumptionist Fathers, to leave London about the end of August, arriving at Marseilles on September 1st, and proceeding through Greece, Turkey, and Egypt. For the first time on record British Roman Catholics will, as such, he officially received by the Sultan of Turkey at Constantinople. The Pope has sent his blessing to the intending pilgrims. According to the present arrangements they will return to London about the middle of October.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
Cairo Industrial School
div.p: Of the pupils of the Industrial School, Cairo, who have undergone the last examination, 37 have obtained the diploma.
The Scott Prize
The first and second scholars of the Khedi- vial Law School, Cairo, who have been granted the “Scott Prize” are Mohamed Eff. Hamdi and Mohamed Eff. Lebib.
New Telegraph Offices

New telegraph offices have been opened in the Mousky and at the Citadel, Cairo. Telegrams for persons resident in these quarters will henceforth be delivered by these offices instead of the office in Boulac-avenue.
New Victoria Hotel

This new first-class establishment was formally opened last Saturday afternoon, when the manager, Mr. Raisig, gave a "five-o’olock” in honour of the event. A large and distinguished gathering, including H.E. the Governor and Mazloum Pacha, availed themselves of Mr. Raisig’s genial hospitality, and did ample justice to a well-stocked buffet. The band of the Royal Dublin Fasiliers played a select repertoire, and in every respect the inauguration was a brilliant success. The new hotel is certainly one of the best in Alexandria. Its position is unique, both for convenience and scenery, the broad expanse of the Mediterranean, two miles distant, being visible from almost every storey on the north side, while the southern side, where the entrance is, looks on to one of the most fashionable thoroughfares of Ramleh. A special feature of the hotel is the balcony which runs round the building and is so agreeable in this hot season. Light and ventilation, roomy and lofty apartments, an excellent cuisine, and moderate fares, these and many other advantages entitle the hotel to the popularity it has already won. A special feature of the decorations are the carpets, which are genuine Persian antiques.
New Books.

In order to continually supply the demands of a public anxious to get the most knowledge in the least time, Mr. Berlitz constantly improves his method and is at work on Borne new books. Two have just been published; the second volume of practical French grammar, and commercial French. These books are immediately placed in all branches of the Berlitz Schools, especially at Cairo (1, Sharia Kamel) and at Alexandria (12, rue Rosette), where the number of successes is ever increasing. [Advt.]

div.head: Army Reduction
Press Alarmed
div.p: PARLIAMENT’S APPALLING FOLLY AND BLINDNESS.
London, July 9

The “Morning Post” and “Daily Telegraph” are alarmed at Mr. Haldane’s schemes for the redaction of the army, and state that they cannot believe that the country will acquiesce. The latter, especially, emphasizes the Moha- medan unrest and concludes that if the present Parliament cannot be checked in its appalling folly and blindness, England may yet find its doom prepared. (Reuter)

div.head: Natal Rebellion
div.p: Rebels Surrounded
Durban, July 9.
The Natal troops completely surrounded the rebel Impi in the Umvoti district, killing 547 of them. Very few rebels escaped. There were no casualties amongst white men. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN UNREST.
div.p: CAPITAL GROWING MORE UNSAFE.
St. Petersburg, July 9.

The city is growing more unsafe. A serious conflict took place last night between revolutionary demonstrators and the Cossacks and police. Many people were wounded. The revolutionaries paraded the streets flying red flags and singing the “Marseillaise.” (Reuter)

div.head: THE CHAMBERLAIN CELEBRATION
BIRMINGHAM’S TRIBUTE.
div.p: London, July 9.

The Chamberlain celebration was the leading feature in the newspapers. By whole-day rejoicings and demonstrations on a marvelous scale Birmingham testified to its devotion and esteem for Mr. Chamberlain. He was the re cipient of congratulatory messages from all parts of the Empire, the Prince of Wales and Lord Northeote being amongst the senders. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MONTAGU.
div.p: STILL ON THE ROCKS.
London, July 9.

In view of an extra high tide yesterday, efforts were made to refloat the Montagu, which were unsuccessful. The attending warships are preparing to leave. There will not be a similar high tide until September. (Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN PRESIDENCY.
MR. BRYAN ACCEPTS NOMINATION.
div.p: Washington, July 9.
Mr. Bryan, in a letter, has intimated his willingness to accept a nomination for the Presidency. (Reuter)

div.head: BRITISH GARRISON IN EGYPT.
Not to be Reduced
div.p: Statement in Parliament.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Tuesday, July 10.

Mr. Walter Runciman stated in the House of Commons yesterday that there was no intention to red ace the British garrison in Egypt, in view of the fanatical feeling that was existing there and in North Africa generally.

div.head: SIR E. GREY’S SPEECH.
MORE NATIVE PRESS COMMENTS.
div.p: “A1 Zahir” writes: The debate on the Denishwai affair in the British Parliament indicates that British statesmen would take revenge on the Egyptian nation for its collective attachment to the Ottoman Government, which was obviously shown daring the Akaba difficulty. The British Minister has employed the Denishwai incident as a means to create some change in Egypt supported by the argument that the Europeans in Egypt—including the English—have become subject to aggression on the part of the natives. Whence did Sir Grey derive his examples of acts of aggression, except from the Denishwai including, in which the Egyptians were unjustly treated and insulted, we cannot comprehend. Every now and then these English people suddenly suspect us of being very fanatical, that is, when they see the right is on our side, and can find no other means of getting rid of responsibility or blame. They now declare that Pan-Islamic fanaticism has extended to the northern parts of Africa, which declaration will serve to stir the minds of other Governments against us, to put us under a heavier burden, and to disturb our peacefulness,—and all this, with a view to damage our national interests and make the world shrink in loathing from us, and to enable England to enjoy an undisturbed preponderance in our country. From the above considerations we gather that the British people would have liked us to praise the activity and wisdom of that special tribunal which has entirely removed from our hearts all sympathy with and inclination towards the British Occupation. Consequently, all that we desire, under the present circumstances, is to be on good and peaceful terms with England, enjoining her to give us our due and be satisfied with her own, bat not to adopt for us a peculiar and can tempt none treatment, which could never be borne even by dumb animals , not to tread ns under foot, depriving ns of all our rights, and keep the word “fanatical” at the tip of her tongue for instant use if we lift our heads to say we are being unjustly treated,' while she secures all rights and benefits for herself. The Egyptians are known to be a peaceful nation; and it is quite astonishing to see England complain of ns. What were the English complaints based on if not on the foot that they intend to advance to the attainment of their political ends at the expense of our imaginary fanaticism?

div.head: THE “WRITING ON THE WALL.”
div.p: Who, we wonder, is responsible for the following mural inscription on the wall of No. 19, Rue Rod el Farag, Cairo :—
Labud min khurog el Ingliz min Masr. Walahnm yom ma’ alüm. Lezim neragga’ el Hikm el Qadim.

div.head: THE DEKHELA OUTRAGE.
O'BRIEN QUESTIONED BY PARQUET.
div.p: Yesterday the Alexandria Parquet authorities went to Ras el-Tin Hospital to hear Private O’Brien’s statements in regard to the attack made against him last week by some natives at Dekhela, near Mex. The soldier’s account of the incident was to the following effect: After receiving his week’s pay, amounting to 5 shillings at Mustapha barracks, O’Brien hired a cab at P.T. 4 to drive him to a place near the Mex slaughter-house, where cabs usually stop, as the road further on is very bad. There he alighted and walked on till he arrived at Bab el Arab, Mex, where he hired a donkey, giving its owner who accompanied him P.T. 3 in advance, and went on towards the camp. On passing by a native café at the old Mex station, O’Brien heard the words "Johnny’s there” uttered by a native, bat he paid no attention and continued riding on, till he was at a distance of about 200 metres from the cafe. There he was attacked by two natives, who had followed him from that caft, one of whom stopped the donkey and pulled him down to the ground, while the other began to search in his pockets. But being unable to discover the money, which the soldier had hidden is his cap, the two vagabonds fell on O’Brien, and after beating him very severely and kicking him till he became unconscious, made off. The donkey boy was then following his donkey, which had run away. Five minutes later another native who spoke some English passed by the soldier and asked what was the matter with him. The soldier told him what had occurred and requested him to accompany him to the camp, which the native did. O’Brien gave him P.T. 2 without any demand for money being made on their arrival at the camp, whence the injured man was taken later to hospital.

The examination showed that O’Brien had come direct from Mustapha. Tae two culprits were brought before the soldier for identification and he easily identified the man who beat him and knelt on his body, bat was not sure whether the other took part in the outrage or not. The donkey boy, however, identified both.
The examination, which was held in the presence of a doctor, lasted an hour, daring which O’Brien spoke without any difficulty.
The trial of the criminals will be held on the 2lst inst. at the Native Court.

div.head: AN INTERESTING REPORT.
div.p: We have received an interesting collection of statistical tables of the working of railways in various countries up to 1901 which has been composed by M. J. D. Diacomidie, engineer to the Egyptian State Railways, which should be of great value for purposes of reference. In comparing the 1904 figures for the Egyptian State Railways with those of other countries one is struck by the large proportion of goods waggons to passenger carriages, 15.1 to 1.6, and the high daily average of passengers per carriage on 100 miles amounting to 19 against an average of 8 for France and 16 for the U. S. A. In length of line open the U. S. A. with over 200,000 miles is easily first, Russia, Germany, and British India following

The U.S.A. again lead in rolling stock with over 41,000locomotives, 34,COO passenger oars, and the prodigious figure of 1,490,000 goods waggons. Great Britain, with 22,443 locomotives, is best supplied with passenger carriages, of which it has 50,728, with nearly three-quarters of a million of goods waggons; and Germany and Russia—both countries in which accommodation for large numbers of troops and military stores most be considered by the State Railways as well as the commercial capacity of the rolling stock—are well off in both. The cost per mile open is highest in Great Britain and Ireland, where it amounts to £56.044, lowest on the companies’ lines in Egypt, £2,874. The highest interest on capital was paid by the Egyptian State Railways in 1904 and amounted to 8 1/5 %, Japan coming next with 1/3 % and then the two chief Dutch lines with 6 4/5 per cent. Mirabils dictu The highest net receipts per train mile are recorded from four of the foreign lines in the Ottoman Empire, though we imagine that what is known as a kilometric guarantee has something to say to this. Altogether Mr. Diacomidis has drawn up a very interesting and valuable report, which we heartily recommend to our readers.

div.head: THE COTTON WORM.
PROGRESS OF DESTRUCTIVE OPERATIONS.
div.p: The report which has been issued by the Ministry of the Interior for the seven days from June 28 to July 4, concerning the progress of the cotton-worm, confirms the news which we published a few days ago as to the success with which the work of its destruction is being carried out. Last year the workof the Ministry of the Interior in this direction was appraised throughout Egypt, and this summerit is still more effective, though perhaps less manifest to the general public.

From June 28 to July 4 it was found that 41,790 feddans of cotton culture, comprising 544 villages inthe provinces of Menofieh, Sharkieh, Behara, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh, Kalioubieh, Ghizeh, and Minieh were affected and were entirely freed from the worm, whereas there were nosigns of the pest in the provinces of Assiout, Beni-Souef, Fayoum, and Keneh. The method followed has been, as was the case last year, that of hand-picking, and it is doubtful if such a method can ever entirely eradicare the orm-indeed its frequesnt recrudescance is a disproof of such a possibility It is, however, a most excellent means of averting the destruction of cotton crops and must be continued until a more lasting measure has been established.

Unfortunately we cannot refard the complete disintection which we have recorded above as a sign of the entire disappearence of the worm in thos districts, as it will inevitably be found that other broods will nake their appearance and have to be treated similarly, and, we trust, with the same excellent result. It must be remembered that three broods appear every summer, and that the progency of this first brood has aksi been destroyed is impossible, on account of the method followed, but we can, nevertheless, regard it as likely to have been considerably reduced. The second brood will in its turn be destroyed in the same manner as has been the first, and the third, which is usually the most prolific, will also be materially diminished. We may, therefore, anticipate even less damage to the crops of the country by cotton-worm than was the case last year, and it is most heartily that we congratulate Mr. Machell, C.M.G., and his assistants on the success with which the campaign that they have organised is meeting. The work has been carried on so unostentatiously this summer that many are ignorant of the prevalence of the fatal prodenia littoralis, but until some means for its ultamite extermination has been discovered the fight must continue year by year.
The following is the official report:--

The operations for the destrution of cotton-wor (prodenia littoralis), which have been undertaken this year, and are similar to those last summer, have been continued during the last week--from June 28 to July 4.
The provinces of Assiout, Beni-Souef, Fayoum,and Keneh have not been affected, while the reports from other provinces for that period are as follows:--
In Menoufish 1,640 feddans have been affected, including 55 villages, and have been cleared.
In Sharkieh 254 feddans, including 20 villages, have been affected and cleared.
In Behra 20,832 feddans, including 215 villages, have been affected and cleared.
In Gharbieh 5,000 feddans, including 85 villages, have been affected and cleared.
In Dakahlieh 8,921 feddans, including 85 villages, have been affected and cleared.
In Kalioubieh 2,681 feddans, including 69 villages, have been affected and cleared.
In Ghixeh 2,327 feddans, including 13 villages, have veen affected and cleared.
In Minieh 145 feddans, including 2 villages, have been affected and cleared.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
"SUNBEAMS, LIMITED"
div.p: To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette.”

Mr. Editor,—I crave a space in your columns to put forth a scheme which I trust may prove of lasting advantage to Egyptian commerce as well as to myself. I was fearing that the recent great influx of capital into Egypt had already reached its anti-climax, and that I should be too late in the day,' when a notice in the “Gazette” of Thursday last that a new company is in course of formation has encouraged me to think that the list of possible concessions is not yet exhausted.

Having, after many years’ residence in Egypt a Government official, wasted the small substance I had accumulated at my bank—not in rioting and wantonness, but in the endeavour to meet the ever-increasing demands of avaricious landlords—I am, naturally, looking for any honourable means of augmenting the annuity which may be allotted to me by a benevolent Ministry when the loss of a limb, a broken heart, or a constitution enfeebled by long residence in the East and a daily course of pale pills for pink people, shall have enabled me to make good my claim. As a patriot I am, of course, desirous, as far as possible, of allowing my native country to benefit by my scheme, which aims, at the same time, at ensuring me the possibility of supporting the change of climate following on my quitting the bright skies of sonny Egypt.
Oh ! blest Retirement ! Friend to life’s decline, Retreat from cares that some day may be mine ! Tis a sad prospect, days of sunshine past, Home to return and die of cold at last.
(I pray that Goldsmith may not “turn in his grave” at this desecration of his immortal verse !)

And, now, for my grand project—Beware of forming too hasty a judgment. You will remember that, one hundred and fifty yean ago, when the learned Barnett, Lord Monboddo, astonished the world with his new monkey theory for the origin of mankind, he was received with a howl of derision and incredulity from the whole body of scientists. And, now, what do we see? The entire category of biologists engaged, ever since Charles Darwin’s death twenty-four years ago, in hunting fora sign of a scrap of the missing tail so scouted of yore!

I trust that you are, now, prepared to learn that my company will aim at no less thou a further development of the project of the professor at the Grand Academy of Lagodo to bottle sunbeams in order to their being used, as required, to warm the air in raw indent sum men. You will, doubtless, remember that, during his eight unsuccessful years of experiment, the worthy professor’s hair and beard had become long, ragged and tinged in several places, and that his clothes and skin were of the same colour. Even then this brave projector had, by no means, lost hope and doubted not that in another eight years he would be able to supply the Governor’s garden with sunshine at a reasons Me rate.

An interesting detail is that the savant was evidently of Egyptian extraction, as he did not foil to ask for and obtain a baksheesh from Captain Lemuet Gulliver. His plan was to extract sunshine from cucumbers; the selection of this plant being due to the fact that in the British climate the fruit is usually grown in hotbeds in which they imbibe, through a glass root such few glimpses of sunshine as an exceptionally warm summer may afford; glimpses all the more valuable and appreciated for their rarity, reminding one of the observation of Sydney Smith in speaking of the brilliant conversation of the eloquent Macao lay, the peculiar charm of which was, he thought, the occasional flash of silence which illuminated it
But, here in Egypt, where cucucmbers are famous for their quality—
"The blazing sans which dart a downward ray And fiercely shed intolerable day”

are so uniformly shiny that the tedious process of extraction may be dispensed with, and we have nothing to do but simply bottle as fast as we can, adopting the months of June. July, and August, tor choice, as the bottling season : this operation once effected, the fortunes of the shareholders will be as good as made.

Another point of economy mast be noticed. The cold storage, so necessary for the transport of tropical fruit and so difficult to find in the Alexandria-home trade, will not be required for bottled sunbeams. In feet, quite the contrary ; the nearer the bottles are stowed to the engines and boilers of the ship the better the chance for the contents to arrive in an unchanged condition at their destination. All we require are good bottles and competent bottlers ; these will be advertised for ip the “Egyptian Gazette” the moment the Financial Adviser and the Council of Ministers have granted the concession.

The learned professor of the Academy of Lagodo was, probably, weak in horticulture. A member of the A. H. 8. would have had greater advantages in cultivation of cucumbers ; especially now that the society has a large garden allotted to it by the Municipality, with a Ministerial subsidy, in view of future export produce. But, as I said before, the time wasted by the professor over sunbeam-cucumbers in Great Britain will be saved under my scheme, and the society’s garden may be retained for the cultivation of edible ones only. I am told, too, by the secretary to the A.H.8. that my project is somewhat beyond the present horizon of the society, which, from mere timidity, prefers to begin by utilising sunbeams in the ordinary way.

My prospectus will shortly be ready for publication; and, in the meantime, Mr. Editor, 1 hope I may count on your valuable aid in making public my design, for the successful issue of which you will have seen that 1 only need a sufficiently credulous and gullible public - in fact, such a one as we are accustomed to see at all times in our own country ready to swallow the fly (with the hook) before it has yet reached the surface of the water.—I am, etc, A.H.S.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES BT CRITIQUES
Le Cairo, Lnndi 9 Jaillet 1906. Vendredi passy, le taux de l’esoompte libre à Londres a été reduit de 1)8 à 3 pour cent.

Ce meme joar, au Stock Exchange, le Con- solide anglais avait baiss6 de 1/4 k 87 5/8. L’Unifiee avait gagne 1/4 fc 105 1/4. Les autres valeurs egyptiennes etaient restees invariees, à l’exception de la Delta Light qui avait repris 1/8 4 11 7/8. A Paris, le Credit Fencier Egyp- tien avait perdu 4 francs 4 753 ; la Banque d’Athenes avait regagne 1 franc a 151.

Samedi. 4 Londres, le Consolide anglais a rattrape 1/8 4 87 3/4. L’Unifiee a perdu 1/2 livre 4 104 3/4. Lea autres valeurs egyptiennes sont demeurees inchangees. A Paris, le Credit Foncier a encore baisae de 1 fr. 4 752. La Banqne d’Athenes eat restee a 151.

Ce matin, notre marche des valeurs ne s'est pes trop departi de son calme de la semaine derniere. Tout au plus peut-on signaler une accentuation du mouvement de reprise quis'etait dessine vendredi dernier sur les Land Allotment.
La National Bank a cloture plus faible a 25 5/16. L'Agricole s'est maintenue a 9 9/16-5/8. La Banque d'Athenes a ete cotee 152.
L'action Credit Foncier s'est raftermie a 755-756 et l'obligation a lots 1886 a 327. La Daira a gagne 1/16 a 17. Par contre, la Behera a perdu 1/2 livre a 35 1/2
L'action Enterprise and Development est revenue a 11 15/16-12 L'Agricole du Nil a progresse de 1 franca 263.
L'action Heliopolis a ete offerte a 286.

En bonne demande, l'action Land Allotment a passe de 3 5/16 a 3 17/32, acheteurs, pour revenir a 3 5/16 et cloturer a 3 1/8 7/16. De meme la part de fondateur, tres recherchee, a hausse de 116 a 128 pour reactionner a 122 et finir 124.
Dns actions privilegees Tramways d'Alexandrie ont avance a 193; les dividendes sont restes a 358.
Les Autombiles se sont consilidees a 4 9/16-5/8.
L'action Bourse Khediviale a ete demandee a 125

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich se sont montres fermes a 15 7/16-1/2 l'action ancienne. Toujours en bonne tendance, les Baehler ont avance a 5 1/2-9/16. Les Upper Egypt se sont raffermies a 4 1/2. Les National ont gagne 1/8 a 3 3/8 1.2. L'anglo American s'est inscrit a 5 3/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Lend ont ete negliges a 3 7/16-12. Les Estates, en bonne tenue, ont cloture a 1 11/16et la part de fondateur a 10 1/4. Les Salt and Soda ont faibli entre 19 sh. 3 et 19 sh. 6.Rien de particulier a relever sur les autres titres de ce compartiment.
A en croire les dernieres informations d'Athenes, l'emission des nouvelles actions de la Banque d'Athenes aursit tres probablement lieu dans les derniers jours du mois courant.

Les parts de dividende (No. 1 a 16,000) de l'Egyptian Enterprise and Development Co. ont ete admises a la cote de la Bourse de Bruxelles depuis le 2 Juillet courant. Ces titres se traitent coupon No. 2, exercice 1906, attache.

On annonce d'Alexandrie que la Societe d'Enterprises Urbaines et Rurales a achete, ces jours derniers, a M. Escoffier, pour la somme de L.E. 17,000 un terrain de 2,000 pics, sis sure les bords du canal Mahmoudieh, pres le palais de Ghazi Moukhtar paoha.

Il ressort du dernieretat comparatif publie par la Societe anonyme de la Brasserie des Pyramides que les ventes de biere et de glace effectuees du 1er Janvier a fin Juin 190sse sont elevees a L.E. 12,990contre 11,072 1/2 pour la periode correspondant de 1905, ce qui represente un surplus de L.E. 1917 1/2 pour l'annee courante.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Commercial, Industrial and Land of Egypt Co. sont informes que le 1er versement de 5 sh. par action est payable le 10 juillet courant aux guichets de la Bank of Egypt, au Cairo et a Alexandrie.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT COMPANY, LIMITED.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above Company will be held at Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad Street, in the City of London on Thursday, the 19th day of July, 1906, at 2 o’clock in the afternoon for the purpose i of considering, and if thought fit, passing the following Resolutions, or Resolutions to la similar effect. If Resolutions 1 to 9 inclusive should be passed by the requisite majority, they will be submitted for confirmation to a subsequent General Meeting to be hereafter convened so as to become Special Resolutions.
RESOLUTIONS

That the Memorandum and Articles of Association be varied as follows :—1. By striking out from Section 3, subsection (a) of the Memorandum of Association the words “in any district” and by sob situating for the words “in which the Railways belonging to or that may at any time hereafter belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, or any extension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constructed or proposed to be constructed, may serve or be intended to serve” occurring in the same subsection the words “or in the Sudan.” 2. That Article 75 of the Articles of Association of the Company be altered by striking out the words commencing “and every exercise of the power” down to the end of that Article. 3. That Article 81 be altered by striking out the words “or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited.” 4. That Article 85 be altered by striking out the words “provided that this prohibition shall not apply to any Contract dealing or transaction with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited.” 5. That Article 86 be altered by striking out all words after the words “shall be vacant.” 6. That Article 87 be altered by striking out the words “save as aforesaid” appearing in the first line of such Article. 7. That Article 89 be struck out and that there be substituted therefor the following Article :— “The remuneration of the Directors “shall he the sum of £250 per annum to “eaoh of the Directors and £500 per “aunum to the Chairman, and snoh “remuneration shall be deemed to aoorne “de die in diem. The remuneration shall “be exclusive of the suoas, if any, which “under the provisions of the3e Presents “the Board may agree to pay to any “Director on account of special services.” 8 That Article 90 be altered by striking out the words “provided he be approved by the Board oi the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited.” 9 That Article 96 be altered by striking out the words “one Director” and sub-stitauting therefor the words “two Directors.” 10 That the Capital of the Company he increased from £250,000 to £500,000. 11 That the Memorandum of Agreement between the Company and the Egyptian Lind and General Trust, Limited, now submitted to the Meeting and initialed by the Chairman for the purposes of identification be approved and authorised to ha entered into (subject to such alterations as the Board may think fit), and that the Board be authorised to enter into such further or other agreements as they may consider desirable for carrying such Memorandum of Agreement into effect. By Order of the Board, F. J. HORNE, Secretary.

Dated 29th Jane, 1906. Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company they mast first deposit their Bearer Warrants,, together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses, either at the Registered Office of the Company in London, two clear days before the Meeting, i.e, not later than the 16th Joly, or with the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, or Alexandria ten dear days before the date of the Meeting, i e., not later than 7 th July, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held.
Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, which must be produced by the holders attending the Meeting.

Copies of two circular letters issued to the Registered Shareholders with this Notice may be obtained upon application at the Offices of the Company, 211-214, Gresham House, Old Broad Street, London, E. C., or from the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo or Alexandria, .Egypt. 28206-6-3

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: The Administration of Wakfs is to sell by public auction, on November 21, between 9 a.m. and 1 p.m., at its offices at Bab-el-Lonk, Cairo, the whole lot of 12 feddans and parts situated at Manial-el-Roda, and belonging to the Wakf of the late Ahmed Pacha el Maneikli. The upset price per feddan is L.E. 3,000
Apply to the said office, on any day except holidays for all particulars relative to the sale. On the day appointed, applicants must present themselves at the same office, with a view to tender.
All tenders must be accompanied by a security amounting in kind equivalent to 20 per cent. of the total price of the said land.
The Administration reserves to itself the right to accept or refuse any tender.

Applicants whose tenders are accepted must in the course of ten days which are to elapse before they are notified thereof give as guarantee for the auction price of the land in question, good cultivable lauds to he valued exclusively by the Administration. 28080-12**

div.head: EXPERIMENTS WITH EGYPTIAN COTTON SEEDS
WORK OF BRITISH COTTON GROWING ASSOCIATION
div.p: At the concluding sitting of the International Cotton congress at Bremen, the Secretary of the British Cotton Growing Association, Mr. J. t\ Atkins, in dealing with the work of the Association in various parts of the world, gave some useful information regarding the numerous experiments with Egyptian seed in North West India, and Central, Eastern, and Southern Africa. At the outset, he pointed out that the necessity for persevering with the work engaged in by the various associations to enlarge the area of cotton cultivation, and thus increase the supply, was still urgent; in fact it was not too much to say that the position grew more serious each year. At present the yield of cotton was greatly reduced. Thus the outlook for supply was not cheerful, and added to this was the extraordinary increase in the number of spindles all over the world, but particularly in Lancashire, one important feature of the increase being that the majority of new mills were for spinning Egyptian qualities. Another development fraught with great possibilities was that the American planters and merchants were combining to limit wherever possible the area of cultivation, and also to influence the market price. The only effectual remedy against these tactics was to open out fresh fields for cotton growing. The British Cotton Growing Association recognised fully the magnitude and difficulty of the task it had undertaken, but having taken the work in ban, every effort would be move to carry it to a succ38sfal issue. The same spirit animated the Continental associations, and, all working with one common object, difficulties would be overcome and success attained. Daring the past year the subscriptions to the Association's capital amounted to about £30,COO, the total amount subscribed to date being £333,000. Despite many discouragements, progress had been made and the Association felt that success would ultimately be achieved. In giving some account of the work in the various Colonies and Dependencies, Mr. Atkins said the Association had succeeded in arousing the Government of India to the necessity of strenuous efforts being made to improve the quality of the cotton growth, and by means of improved cultivation to increase the quantity. The Agricultural Department had taken up the question--duly qualified men were conducting experiments in various districts, seed farms had been established, and efforts were being made to improve the position of small native planters, and so enable them to avail themselves of anyimproved methods of cultivation, and to secure proper seed.with that objectit was probable an attempt would be made to introduce agricultural banks similar to those which had been such a great success in Egypt. Large experiments were being made with tree cotton, several varieties of which had grown wild in many parts of the country. Owing to adverse climatic conditions no definite results had been secured ; sufficient cotton was grown, however, to give hopes of success in the future. In Sinde (North West India), where the conditions were somewhat similar to Egypt, experi-ments with several varieties of Egyptian seed were being carried on by the Government Agricultural Department. The reuslts were very encouraging; a lot of eleven bales grown last season sent to the Association had recently been sold at 9d. per pound. messrs. Ralli Bros, imported about 500 bales of the same cotton, which they valued at 10d. There was therefore every encouragement to push forward vigorously the growth of Egyptian cotton in this province. The Association, in order to assist the efforts of the Indian Government, has agreed to contribute £10,000 towards the expenses incurred in placing the industry on a better basis. Marked success had attended the efforts of the Association in the various West Indian Islands. Although it was only four years since the industry was started it had rapidly developed, and was now on a commercial basis. The cotton was of a very fine quality, and had fetched prices ranging from 12d. to 20d per pound. Several ginning factories had been established with the Association's assistance, and recently a mill had been erected in Barbados for crushing the seed, and if successful would be followed by others. The production of cotton bade fair to bring renewed prosperity to the West Indies. In British Central Africa cotton growing was taken up entusiastically two years ago by the European farmersin the neighbourhood of Blantyre. Unfortunatly in the past two seasons the weather has been very unfavourable, and severla of the plantations were a failure. Some were very successful, and very fine cotton from Egyptian seed had been grown. About 4,000 bales were produced last season, and much more was expected this year. Efforts were being made through the Government to induce the Datives to grow cotton, and large quantities of seed bad been distributed. The Association had spent a considerable amount of money, to start the industry and firmly believed that ultimately success would be attained. In British East Africa it had been proved that good cotton could be grown from Egyptian seed on the coast lands also in the neighbourhood of Lake Victoria Nyanza. It was confidently believed that a profitable industry would soon be established. The Association had erected a ginnery near Mombasa*, and bad under Consideration a scheme to greatly extend the area under cultivation, by encouraging settlers and natives to plant cotton, and by opening baying centres. In the enormous territory of Rhodesia the experiments had proved that good cotton could

be grown. Works on a large scale was about to be commenced by the Association, the British South Africa Company, and others. Here Egyptian and good stapled American cotton would be grown. About 200 bales (Egyptian) were recently sold in Liverpoolat 8d and 9d. per lb. In Cape Colony, Natal, the Transvaal, and Orange River Colonies much interest has been created, and the Association has received samples from many planters who had grown very good cotton experimentally. Every encouragement had been giver, and a large number of band gins sent oat, and who especially selected seed. In those Colonies it was a question if cotton could be produced profitably, owing to the cost of labour. There were great possibilities in Upper Egypt and the Sedan for the growth of Egyptian cotton. The development was retarded by the scarcity of labour and want of water, but both would be remedied in time On the West Coast of Africa we had several colonies where cotton was indigenous, and had been grown by the natives for ages. The cotton was mostly of inferior quality, and had been used locally. The Association had set itself to encourage the natives to grow better cotton, and in increasing quantities. With that object good seed bad been largely distributed, ginneries had been erected, and buying agencies established. A very good quality of cotton could be grown in Q ueensland and in the Northern Territories of South Australia. It was duabtful, however, if it could be profitably grown owing to the cost of labour. The Agricultural Department was taking a keen interest, and was very anxious to introduce cotton as a permanent industry, and every effort would be made to that end. In Ceylon, Cyrprus,BritishGuiana, and many other places cotton was being grown in small quantities and the Association was giving assistance. The association was in communication with almost every part of the Empire, and owing to its efforts attentionhad been drawn to the great advantages to be derived from cotton growing. The successes already achieved had encouraged inquiries with regard to other products, and great development might be expected which owuld resutlt in mutual benefit to the mother country and the colonies. it had been proved that cotton of all grades could be grown within the British Empire. The Association encouraged by the successes, would preserve until the industry was placed on a sound basis in those colonies most suited to the growth of cotton. It was not only necessary to grow cotton, but to produce it at such a price that it might be delivered in England to yield a profit to all concerned. The association was sanguins that this could be done, and firmly believed that the time was not far and distant when a sufficient supply would be obtained to render the cotton trade of England in a great measure independent of America for its raw materials. In conclusion he claimed that the British Cotton Growing Association had justified its existence. It was engaged in a truly Imperial work, and was steadily pushing forward, undaunted by tailures here and there, towards the ultimate realisatin of the most sanguine expectations.

div.head: SIR JOHN FRENCH AND THE INDIAN COMMAND
div.p: There is no truth, the "Telegraph" states, in the report that Sir John D.P. French is about to take over the Indian command, in immediate succession to Lord Kitchener. Sir John, under whose indomitable energy, wide experience, and profound technical skill the Aldershot command, or Army Corps, has been so highly trained and has reached such a high degree of excellence, will remain for a year beyond the ordinary time limit in charge of that force. The “Telegraph's” French correspondents state that Lieut-General Sir John French, accompanied by members of his staff, will officially attend this years Army manoeuvres in that country sometime in September next

div.head: MACEDONIAN REFORM
THE PERVESITY OF THE SULTAN
div.p: In the House of Lords, last week, Lord j Newton called attention to the proposed | increase in the Turkish customs duties. He thought the time had come when we ought to make terms Dot only with Germany, but with the Turkish Government At long as the Turkish Customs remained as at present we I were in a strong position. We bad a good card in our hand—we had something to bargain with, but if we surrendered that petition without obtaining a proper equivalent we were to a great extent weakening our bargain, and therefore he urged that a favourable opportunity had now occurred for making a bargain with Germany and Turkey with regard to the Bagdad Railway scheme before we finally assented to an increase of Customs duties
MASTERS OF THE SITUATION

Lord Fitzmaurioe stated that the question was closely allied to Macedonian reforms. As they were only accpted last December it was our duty to give them some time to operate The Government would not have met with the approval of eith3r House of Parliament if they had not adhered strictly to the policy of their predecessors in insisting that adequate guarantees should be forthcoming that the money wouldfind its way into the Macedonian villagers, and not go to Constantinople to be played with or used for any purpose the Turkish Government thought necessary. The government had shown in unmistakable terms that they had no intention of receding from their demands, but daring the last few days the Turkish Government had sent in a reply which practically placed the negotiations in exactly the same position they occupied when the late Government left office The responsibility of this lay with the Turkish Government. His Majesty’s Government were entirely absolved from those unwarrantable and rather hasty imputations which had been made that the Turkish Government had practically shown themselves to be the masters of the situation. It might be possible that other fands not derived from an increase of the Customs duties might be used for the purpose of subsidising the Bagdad Railway, but what the Government insisted upon was that the proposed increase in the Customs should not be use^ or any other parp036 than that specifiedd in the Note. If the Turkish Government realised that we had gone as far as was possible acceding to their demands, we should be fully justified in telling them that they mustadopt the only other remedy, namely, that they most remedy the enormous military force, which, he thought, they kept up quite. unnecessarily.

div.head: "STIFFEN THE CONDITIONS"
div.p: The Marquis of lansdowne would have congratulate the Government if they had told the House that they had found it possible make a thoroughly satisfactory settlment to make a thoroughly satisfactory settlement of this most difficult and embarrassing question. It was dear, however, once again, that the perversity of the Turkish Government had made it impossible to come to an arrangement which, upon the whole, would have been very advantageous to Turkey. He regretted the interruption of negotiations the less because he was not without hope that should they hereafter he renewed the Government might find it possible to somewhat stiffen their conditions, sod really open what was described as a new chapter in the lamentable history of these transactions. We had had bitter experience of the value of Turkish promises, and be should be glad if it could be made a condition of settlement that the three per cent. increase of Customs duties should not he allowed to come into operation until by an experience spread over certain time we had become satisfied that the ways of the Turkish Customs authorities had been practically mended. The real return which we expected to get for agreeing to the three per cent. increase was that there should be better government in the Macedonian vilayets. The present condition of Macedonia was a constant menace to the peace of Europe, and it was to the best interests of this country and to the interests of all the civilized Powers that the condition of these regions should be improved. If there was to be a renewal of the negotiations he treated for our own sake that we should read the Turkish Government a lesson which they deserved, and insist upon conditions not only as stringent as those they had rejected, hut impose heavier obligations upon them.

div.head: THE PORTE'S LAST MOVE
div.p: The Marquis of Ripon said the Government had endeavoured to lay down conditions for acceptance by the Turkish Government which had been proposed by the late Government, but unfortunately up to the present they had not been successful. The last communication from the Porte led them to think that the negotiations might be considered to have come to an end. If the negotiation failed to bring about a settlement on the lines laid down, the hands of the Government would be freed, and it would be for the Fri, 13 Porte to consider whether the rejection of those condition would not entitle this country and the other Powers to pat forward other proposals and impose other conditions in San. 15 order to bring a question which threatened j the peace of Europe to a final and satisfsctory conclusion.
The subject then dropped.

div.head: THE ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY
div.p: During the last few months little has happened to remove the doubts and anxieties which surround the relations between the Abyssinian Government and the Ethiopian Railway Company. Urging the importance of England, France, and Italy arriving at an early settlement, the "Morning Post” says :—“There is every reason to suppose that the Emperor Menelik is seriously annoyed by the delay. He has gone so far as to announce that unless the efforts of diplomacy succeed in circum- venting the present impasse he himself will undertake the completion of the line. Indeed, he has at his own expense constructed the preliminary works for some thirty kilometres from Adis Adeba. The question at once arises: From what source is he likelyto obtain the necessary funds? In regard to this matter it is significant that while the governments of the three Powers immediately concerned are still unable to put an end to the deadlock, Germany has already made great strides towards securing a footing at the Abyssinian Court. Without entering into the designs which underlie this movement, it is at least worth pointing out that it would be a sorry conclusion to the labours of the last ten years if the motive power behind the Abyssinian railway were eventually to be located in Berlin. It is carious that no official announcement has been made by the British Government on a subject which so intimately concerns the interests of this country and our relations with France.”

The “ Petite Republique ” learns that M. Cambon’s interviews with Sir Edward Grey and Signor Tittoni justify the statement that the period of hesitation and postponement concerning the Abyssinian Agreement is ended. Great Britain, Italy, and France. says the journal, have agreed to maintain the statusquoin Abyssinia, and not to alter it until they have settled the matter among themselves. Other clauses stipulatefor the establishment of an open door and econoic equality for all nations.

It is a well-known fact (says the Paris correspondednt of the "standard") that the Ethipoian Railway Company has, to put it mildly, been badly managed. It will be reconstructed and reorganised financially and administratively. In conceding a monopoly to this company, Italy and Great Britain have arranged for the protection of international interests in what is likely to be considered an adequate manner. Exactly what the arrangement is I cannot at this stage of the negotiations say. I can only state that it is fair and necessary in view of the power vested in the company, and that Frenchmen will have no reasonable objection to urge against it.

Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER
BREMEN.
Obtainable from every Respectable Firm In Cairo, Alexandria & the Sudan.
Otherwise apply to
V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria
